G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody or parenting plan may be modified upon a showing of a material change in circumstances and where modification advances the best interests of the children.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20 and c. 208, § 28, as this Court issued the original custody order on or about April 15, 2021.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 23.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 23, as both parties and the minor children reside in Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

*R.H. v. B.F.*, 429 Mass. 803 (1999) (a.raw_text: *R.H. v. B.F.*, 429 Mass. 803 (1999) (a material change may include a parent’s inability to fulfill parenting duties).
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 429 Mass. 803 (1999) (a.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody or parenting plan may be modified upon a showing of a material change in circumstances and where modification advances the best interests of the children.
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 429 Mass. 803 (1999) (a.case_name: General Electric Co. v. Department of Environmental Protection
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 429 Mass. 803 (1999) (a.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a public-records / work-product case involving the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection and GE; it does not concern G.L. c. 208, § 28, divorce, custody, or modification of parenting plans. The court’s analysis is confined to statutory construction of the public records statute and its exemptions, and contains no discussion of material change in circumstances, best interests of children, or any family-law standard. It therefore cannot support the stated custody‑modification proposition.
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 429 Mass. 803 (1999) (a.relevant_excerpt: The opinion focuses on whether materials privileged as work product are exempt from disclosure under the public records statute: “Our conclusion that materials privileged as work product pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 26 (b) (3) … are not protected from disclosure under the public records statute unless those materials fall within the scope of an express statutory exemption, is based on several considerations. General Laws c. 66, § 10, provides that ‘[e]very person having custody of any public record … shall … permit it … to be inspected….’” This has no relation to custody modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28.

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..raw_text: *Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015) (the court must place the best interests of the children at the forefront when evaluating custody modifications).
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody or parenting plan may be modified upon a showing of a material change in circumstances and where modification advances the best interests of the children.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody, visitation, abuse, and removal, but it does not concern or apply G.L. c. 208, § 28, nor does it articulate the specific standard for modification of existing custody or parenting plans (material change in circumstances plus best interests). The quoted portions focus on initial custody determinations under §§ 31 and 31A, and removal under § 30, not post‑judgment modification. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the claimed § 28 modification standard.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child. … ‘[I]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.’ … In exercising discretion, the judge is authorized ‘to consider the widest range of permissible evidence.’” (88 Mass. App. Ct. at 245-246).

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).raw_text: *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (emphasizing that custody decisions must reflect current circumstances impacting parental availability).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a change in a parent’s work schedule or inability to provide appropriate care constitutes a basis for custody modification.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a relocation/removal case focused on the best‑interests standard where parents share joint physical custody; it does not discuss modification of custody based on a parent’s changed work schedule or inability to provide care. The court mentions the father’s employment history only as background and does not treat it as a basis for modifying custody. There is no holding or reasoning in Mason v. Coleman that a change in work schedule or caregiving capacity, by itself, constitutes grounds for custody modification.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion. … Where physical custody is shared, the ‘best interest’ calculus pertaining to removal is appreciably different from those situations that involve sole physical custody.… We turn to the propriety of the judge’s order denying permission for the mother to remove the children. The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move.”

See *Hourihan v. Hourihan*, 60 Mass. App.raw_text: See *Hourihan v. Hourihan*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 808 (2004) (reaffirming the need for a parent to demonstrate consistent availability during parenting time).
See *Hourihan v. Hourihan*, 60 Mass. App.proposition: Courts routinely modify orders under such circumstances.

*A.H. v. M.P.*, 447 Mass. 828 (2006) (no.raw_text: *A.H. v. M.P.*, 447 Mass. 828 (2006) (non-parental involvement in custody contexts must be scrutinized to protect children’s welfare).
*A.H. v. M.P.*, 447 Mass. 828 (2006) (no.proposition: Leaving the children with a roommate whose competence is unverified raises concerns about their safety and welfare.
*A.H. v. M.P.*, 447 Mass. 828 (2006) (no.support_reasoning: The case concerns when and how non-parents (such as former same‑sex partners) may obtain de facto parent or parent‑by‑estoppel status and how courts should intrude into family autonomy to protect a child’s best interests. It does not discuss leaving children with roommates, nor does it establish any rule about the risks of entrusting children to an unvetted non‑parent caregiver. The opinion is about defining and limiting non‑parent parental status, not about third‑party babysitting or supervision decisions by a legal parent.
*A.H. v. M.P.*, 447 Mass. 828 (2006) (no.relevant_excerpt: “Recognition of de facto parentage lies within the Probate and Family Court’s general equity powers pursuant to G. L. c. 215, § 6, to protect the welfare of minors. … It proceeds from the premise ‘that disruption of a child’s preexisting relationship with a nonbiological parent can be potentially harmful to the child,’ thus warranting State intrusion into the private realm of the family. … A judge has broad discretion to consider any factor that bears on the child’s best interests.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.raw_text: *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981) (noting that custody must prioritize maintaining a stable and nurturing environment for the child).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Courts have emphasized that stability, predictability, and the children’s overall well-being are paramount in custody determinations.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion directly frames custody determinations around the children’s best interests, happiness, welfare, and the need to minimize disruption and foster a healthy environment. It emphasizes that joint custody is appropriate only where parents can cooperate in a relatively stable, amicable fashion, and the court upholds sole custody to the primary nurturing parent to avoid conflict and promote the children’s well-being. This aligns with the proposition that stability, predictability, and overall well-being are paramount in custody decisions.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

See *Adoption of Mariano*, 77 Mass. App..raw_text: See *Adoption of Mariano*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 656 (2010) (highlighting the importance of consistent parental supervision to promote a child’s welfare).
See *Adoption of Mariano*, 77 Mass. App..proposition: A modification of the existing order is critical to ensuring that the children have appropriate and consistent caregiving arrangements aligned with their developmental needs.
See *Adoption of Mariano*, 77 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on whether to allow a single‑parent adoption that would terminate the father’s parental rights, applying a best‑interests analysis centered on preserving the child’s economic benefits and potential relationship with his biological father. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody or parenting order, nor does it address ensuring ‘appropriate and consistent caregiving arrangements’ aligned with developmental needs. The case is about maintaining a legal parent‑child relationship, not about restructuring or modifying caregiving arrangements, so it does not support the cited proposition.
See *Adoption of Mariano*, 77 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s preservation of a parental relationship between the father and the child rests well within the boundaries of sound discretion. It serves the ‘best interests’ of the child as illustrated in the leading cases… The parents’ mutual antagonism and wish for adoption do not override the child’s best interests in the identification of a biological father and in the potentiality of the guidance, companionship, and affection of that biological father either now or later.”
